items.content_html:
Request for position on an emerging web specification

  • WebKittens who can provide input: @msaboff, @annevk

Information about the specification

  • Title: Use v flag instead of u for HTML pattern attribute RegExps
  • URL: whatwg/html#7908
  • GitHub repository: whatwg/html#7908
  • Issue Tracker (if not the repository's issue tracker): whatwg/html#7908
  • Explainer (if not README.md in the repository): whatwg/html#7908

Design reviews and vendor positions

  • TAG Design Review: N/A
  • Mozilla standards-positions issue: mozilla/standards-positions#745

Bugs tracking this feature

  • WebKit Bugzilla: https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=251675
  • Radar: rdar://problem/105268069

Anything else we need to know

The proposed change to the HTML pattern attribute swaps the u RegExp flag for the new v flag, enabling the use of three new features:

  • set notation
  • string literal syntax
  • Unicode properties of strings

The spec patch at whatwg/html#7908 lists the potentially breaking changes. Some patterns that previously would compile, now throw an early error with the v flag — specifically those with a character class including either an unescaped special character or a double punctuator.

We expect such patterns to be rare. To validate those assumptions we’ve added two use counters to Chromium: V8RegExpUnicodeSetIncompatibilitiesWithUnicodeMode tracks patterns in any JavaScript u RegExps (not just those implicitly generated via the pattern attribute) that would throw if they were used with the v flag, and HTMLPatternRegExpUnicodeSetIncompatibilitiesWithUnicodeMode does the same thing for the smaller & more relevant set of RegExps that are compiled via the HTML pattern attribute.

Importantly, note that throwing patterns result in inputElement.validity.valid === true for any input value (as if the pattern attribute wasn’t present), so the only compatibility risk is that some value/pattern combinations that would previously result in inputElement.validity.valid === false now result in inputElement.validity.valid === true. So even if the UseCounters are non-zero, it could be that there is no actual breakage.
items.title: Request for position: Use `v` flag instead of `u` for HTML `pattern` attribute RegExps

Anything else we need to know

The initial FedCM API had positive signal from WebKit. This is an additional feature for users who have created a federated account in the past (conceptually the same as mediation: silent in CredentialManagement API).

items.content_html:
Request for position on an emerging web specification

  • WebKittens who can provide input: @annevk

Information about the specification

  • Title: Skip service worker no-op fetch handler
  • URL: w3c/ServiceWorker#1671
  • GitHub repository: https://github.com/yoshisatoyanagisawa/service-worker-skip-no-op-fetch-handler/

Design reviews and vendor positions

  • TAG Design Review: w3ctag/design-reviews#815
  • Mozilla standards-positions issue: mozilla/standards-positions#744

Anything else we need to know

Some sites have a no-op (no operation) fetch handler (e.g. onfetch = () => {}). Since having the fetch handler was one of the requirements to be a progressive web app (PWA), we assume they did that to make their site recognized as PWA. However, it only brings overheads to start a service worker and execute a no-op handler without bringing any feature benefits like caching or offline capabilities because the code does nothing. To make the navigation to such pages faster, we would like to omit the service worker start and the handler execution from the navigation critical path if a user agent identifies that the service worker fetch handler is no-op.

This is mostly a behind-the-scenes performance improvement. However, it can subtly change the behavior in edge cases, such as dynamically-updated fetch handlers.
items.title: Skip service worker no-op fetch handler

items.content_html:
Request for position on an emerging web specification

(Please delete inapplicable rows.)

  • WebKittens who can provide input: @annevk (probably others but I don't know who)

Information about the specification

  • Title: Permissions Policy: Unload
  • URL: https://github.com/fergald/docs/blob/master/explainers/permissions-policy-unload.md
  • GitHub repository: https://github.com/fergald/docs
  • Issue Tracker (if not the repository's issue tracker):
  • Explainer (if not README.md in the repository): https://github.com/fergald/docs/blob/master/explainers/permissions-policy-unload.md

Design reviews and vendor positions

  • TAG Design Review: w3ctag/design-reviews#738
  • Mozilla standards-positions issue: mozilla/standards-positions#691

Bugs tracking this feature

  • WebKit Bugzilla:
  • Radar:

Anything else we need to know

Brief summary of the issue or the subject of the specification.

Unload handlers are unreliable in a non-deterministic way. If the page can be BFCached, they do not run on WebKit at all or on mobile Mozilla and Chrome (and they block BFCache on desktop Mozilla/Chrome). This proposal gives a way to deterministically prevent them from running in the given frame and/or selected subframes. This allows a controlled migration away from unload handlers.
items.title: Permissions Policy: Unload

items.content_html:
Request for position on an emerging web specification

  • WebKittens who can provide input: @annevk

Information about the specification

  • Title: MathML Core (mtd@colspan)
  • URL: https://w3c.github.io/mathml-core/#entry-in-table-or-matrix-mtd

Design reviews and vendor positions

  • Mozilla standards-positions issue: mozilla/standards-positions#743

Bugs tracking this feature

  • WebKit Bugzilla: https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=251489

Anything else we need to know

MathML 3 has an attribute called columspan [1] that is implemented in WebKit relying on the implementation of HTML's colspan attribute [2].

MathML Core instead switches to colspan for consistency with HTML [3] and clarifies things like parsing. In particular this makes things confusing for users who are familiar with HTML.

Would WebKit be interested in supporting this name (together with the legacy name columnspan)?

[1] https://www.w3.org/TR/MathML3/chapter3.html#presm.mtdatts
[2] https://searchfox.org/wubkat/search?q=columnspan&path=&case=true&regexp=false
[3] https://w3c.github.io/mathml-core/#entry-in-table-or-matrix-mtd
items.title: MathML colspan attribute for the `<mtd>` element

items.content_html:
Request for position on an emerging web specification

  • WebKittens who can provide input: @annevk @johnwilander

Information about the specification

  • Title: requestStorageAccessForOrigin
  • GitHub repository: https://github.com/privacycg/requestStorageAccessForOrigin

Design reviews and vendor positions

  • TAG Design Review: To be filed; will update once ready.
  • Mozilla standards-positions issue: mozilla/standards-positions#736

Anything else we need to know

The proposed requestStorageAccessForOrigin API builds on the Storage Access API to allow non-iframe use. This affords more control for the top-level site as cross-site cookies continue to be phased out; it also allows partial restoration of the page-level behavior of requestStorageAccess, which will be retired in favor of a per-frame model. Like requestStorageAccess, implementation-defined behavior allows different user agents flexibility to apply policies as they see fit, though the hope is that divergence will be minimized.

Note that this proposal is similar to an internal shim API implemented by both Safari and Firefox.

Prior discussions have surfaced the need for embeddee opt-in, which the API attempts to ensure via requiring invocation of requestStorageAccess for frame-level access (the same way a prior requestStorageAccess grant is proposed to waive the user interaction requirement in the per-frame requestStorageAccess model); requiring CORS on subresource requests to the embeddee from the top-level site in order for cookies to be included; and applying only to explicitly SameSite=None cookies.
items.title: requestStorageAccessForOrigin

There is no explainer. Here are some within the latest Editor's Draft (formerly called "Level 2").

  1. upgrading passive mixed content (audio, video, img elements) on HTTPS pages without a fallback
  2. deprecation of CSP block-all-mixed-content
  3. warnings for insecure downloads (OK to leave out in this standards position for now)

items.content_html:
Request for position on an emerging web specification

  • WebKittens who can provide input: @litherum

Information about the specification

  • Title: Canvas Formatted Text
  • GitHub repository: https://github.com/WICG/canvas-formatted-text/
  • Explainer:
    • https://github.com/WICG/canvas-formatted-text/blob/main/README.md
    • https://github.com/WICG/canvas-formatted-text/blob/main/explainer-datamodel.md
    • https://github.com/WICG/canvas-formatted-text/blob/main/explainer-metrics.md
    • https://github.com/WICG/canvas-formatted-text/blob/main/explainer-rendering.md
  • Authors: @dlibby-, @ijprest, @sushraja-msft, @travisleithead

Anything else we need to know

I previously worked on Intl.Segmenter, which was attempting to solve parts of this problem (linguistically aware line breaking, a frequent request which we have heard in ECMA-402). As @litherum explained, the text-only approach is incorrect, and we need something integrated with multiline text rendering tc39/proposal-intl-segmenter-v2#8.

An alternative for some use cases would be to avoid using canvas for text and use HTML rendering. This is possible for some applications and not others.

The reason I'm asking about this API: Bloomberg is looking at improvements to text rendering in the charts within one of our iOS apps, which are rendered in a <canvas> in a WKWebView, with text currently drawn with the fillText API. We're looking at this API in parallel with investigating whether we could take the HTML approach to avoid its need.
items.title: Request for Position: Canvas Formatted Text

  • WebKittens who can provide input: @youennf

Information about the specification

  • Title: (part of webrtc-extensions)
  • URL: https://w3c.github.io/webrtc-extensions/#disable-hardware
  • GitHub repository: https://github.com/w3c/webrtc-extensions

Design reviews and vendor positions

  • TAG Design Review: (to be determined if this is necessary)
  • Mozilla standards-positions issue: mozilla/standards-positions#728

Bugs tracking this feature

  • WebKit Bugzilla:
  • Radar:

Anything else we need to know

The hardware encoders used by Safari are problematic as well as seen from these issues from the list-of-doom:
iPadOS 15 / iOS 15 unable to decode VP9 stream
https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=230604#c11

Safari: VP9-SVS no video stream from remote peer on some devices
https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=231074

Apple Silicon: Black screen share on remote side of peerconnection
https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=236870

and last but not least the infamous https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=232006
items.title: Request for Position: programatically disabling hardware encoding/decoding in WebRTC

items.content_html:
Request for position on an emerging web specification

  • WebKittens who can provide input:

Information about the specification

  • Title: CSS Inline 3
  • URL: https://drafts.csswg.org/css-inline-3/#baseline-source
  • GitHub repository: https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts

Design reviews and vendor positions

  • TAG Design Review:
  • Mozilla standards-positions issue: mozilla/standards-positions#727

Bugs tracking this feature

  • WebKit Bugzilla: https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=249094
  • Radar:

Anything else we need to know

The "baseline-source" properties allows web developers to specify if an inline-level box should use the "first" or "last" baseline for alignment within an linebox.

Today the default behaviour is confusing for web developers. Consider:

test <div style="display: inline-block;">line1<br>line2</div>
test <div style="display: inline-flex;">line1<br>line2</div>

The "inline-block" will align to the last baseline, and the "inline-flex" will align to the first baseline.

baseline-source: auto is the existing (confusing) behaviour.

Web developers can specify baseline-source: first or baseline-source: last to directly determine how they want these boxes to align within a line-box.

See demo here: https://twitter.com/bfgeek/status/1612518098611089408
items.title: baseline-source CSS property

Request for position on an emerging web specification

(Please delete inapplicable rows.)

  • WebKittens who can provide input:

Information about the spec

  • Spec Title: Multi-Screen Window Placement API
  • Spec URL: https://www.w3.org/TR/window-placement/
  • GitHub repository:
  • Issue Tracker (if not the repository's issue tracker):
  • Explainer (if not README.md in the repository):

Design reviews and vendor positions

  • TAG Design Review:
  • Mozilla standards-positions issue:

Bugs tracking this feature

  • WebKit Bugzilla:
  • Radar:

Anything else we need to know

"The Multi-Screen Window Placement API allows you to place windows on any display connected to your machine, store that placement, and make a window full-screen on any display. With this API, a presentation app can show slides on one screen and speaker notes on another. An art or music creation app can place palettes on a second screen. And a restaurant can show a touchscreen menu on a kiosk and a separate window for employees."
items.title: Multi-Screen Window Placement API

items.content_html:
Request for position on an emerging web specification

(Please delete inapplicable rows.)

  • WebKittens who can provide input:

Information about the spec

  • Spec Title: Prefetch processing model
  • Spec URL: whatwg/html#8111
  • GitHub repository: https://github.com/whatwg
  • Issue Tracker (if not the repository's issue tracker):
  • Explainer (if not README.md in the repository):

Design reviews and vendor positions

  • TAG Design Review:
  • Mozilla standards-positions issue: mozilla/standards-positions#723

Bugs tracking this feature

  • WebKit Bugzilla: https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=194539
  • Radar: rdar://problem/3176096

Anything else we need to know

Some details in the proposal to align over:

  • Prefetch is essentially designed to populate the HTTP cache at low priority, for subsequent navigations and resource loads.
  • The Accept header for prefetch is defined as the same one that is sent with frame navigation. This prevents double-prefetches with Vary: Accept. See whatwg/fetch#1485
  • Sending Sec-Purpose for prefetches, to allow servers to discern between regular requests and resource hints. See whatwg/fetch#1576
  • Using "least restrictive" CSP directive. See w3c/webappsec-csp#582
items.title: Request for position: aligning on <link rel=prefetch>
